a:1:{i:0;a:2:{s:5:"title";s:46:"Understanding IELTS Writing Assessment Criteria";s:7:"content";s:1289:"How Your IELTS Writing is Assessed When an IELTS examiner marks your writing, they evaluate your work using four distinct criteria. Each criterion carries equal weight in determining your final band score. 1. Task Achievement (Task 1) / Task Response (Task 2) This criterion assesses whether you have fully addressed all parts of the task. For Task 1, it evaluates how well you describe the visual information, present an overview, and highlight key features. For Task 2, it looks at how well you present and develop your position, ideas, and arguments. Meeting the minimum word count (150 words for Task 1, 250 words for Task 2) is essential. 2. Coherence and Cohesion This evaluates the organization of your writing. Examiners look at how logically you arrange information and ideas, how well you structure paragraphs, and how effectively you use cohesive devices (linking words such as however, furthermore, in addition, on the other hand) to connect your ideas. 3. Lexical Resource This assesses your vocabulary range and the accuracy of word choice. Examiners evaluate whether you can use less common vocabulary, demonstrate awareness of style and collocation, and skillfully paraphrase without copying directly from the task prompt. 4. Grammatical Range and Accuracy This criterion evaluates the variety of sentence structures you use and how accurately you use grammar. Examiners look for a mix of simple, compound, and complex sentences, correct use of grammar, and proper punctuation.";}}
